awd_titl_txt: MIT Materials Research Science and Engineering Center - Full Proposal
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical abstract
MIT has an exceptionally strong and wide-ranging effort in materials science and engineering that cuts across eleven different academic departments in the schools of science and engineering. The MIT MRSEC, locally known as the Center for Materials Science and Engineering (CMSE), is a cross-school interdisciplinary center that plays the critical role of bringing this diverse materials community together by encouraging and supporting collaborative research and innovative educational and industrial outreach programs. The mission of the MRSEC is to encourage high impact, fundamental research and education in the science and engineering of materials in support of existing and emerging technologies that will address the current and future needs of society. To accomplish this mission, CMSE enables collaborative interdisciplinary research among MIT faculty and between MIT faculty and the researchers of other universities, industry, and government laboratories. Another key objective is the development of state-of-the-art shared facilities that provide and maintain critically enabling instrumentation for CMSE MRSEC investigators and the broader MIT and US materials community. The center offers several education and outreach programs including programs directed at middle and high school students, K-12 teachers, women and minorities, undergraduates, and graduate students.
 
Technical abstract
The MRSEC research program supports collaborative, interdisciplinary research that addresses important complex problems not easily solved without a diverse team of researchers from different fields. This objective is realized through the support of interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs), seed projects, and shared experimental facilities (SEFs). In IRG-1, the focus is on detailed fundamental studies of in-fiber fluid instabilities in multiple fluid systems.  From this fundamental research will arise new processing paradigms for creating nanospheres of arbitrary size, geometry and composition with expected discoveries, both fundamental and applied, spanning novel neuronal interface devices, delivery vehicles for pharmaceuticals, and potentially in the chemical and electronics industries.  IRG-II focuses on unraveling the multi-faceted interplay of structural elements in complex biological hydrogels.  This group seeks to understand the fundamental biology, chemistry and materials science underlying the unique properties of biological hydrogels and use this knowledge to design and create synthetic mimics that have the potential to revolutionize the design of water purification technologies and a range of biomedical applications. Finally, IRG-III focuses on a key unresolved issue in materials with oxygen defects: namely, what coupling mechanisms exist between oxygen defects and the transport of phonons, spin and charge at the interfaces of complex oxides.  The resultant basic science could provide the foundation for the development of a new generation of high-efficiency energy conversion and storage devices.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
MIT MRSEC research, educational outreach, and industry interactions have had many important impacts, from educating the next generation of scientific leaders to generating groundbreaking science and transferring critical fundamental knowledge to industry. The MRSEC Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs) have published more than 210 peer-papers and have been granted more than 35 patents.  The work is highly collaborative, both amongst researchers within the MRSEC and through >70 external collaborations, >30 of which are international. More than 60 graduate students and postdocs have been trained in highly interdisciplinary research, launching impactful careers in academia, industry, and at national laboratories. Coordinated educational outreach activities have had far-ranging impact on students, teachers, and the public. Through these synergistic efforts, the MIT MRSEC has succeeded in enabling interdisciplinary fundamental research and substantive educational outreach with significant societal impact.

 Intellectual Merit:

IRG-I research is directed at the development of unique, multi-component nano-structured fibers and nano-particles through the use of a newly discovered processing paradigm involving nonlinear in-fiber fluid instabilities. IRG-1 developed a new paradigm for fluid dynamics studies in a highly controlled environment, for observation of fluid instabilities in hitherto unobtainable geometries and scales. Fundamental insights have yielded a materials-agnostic approach for the manufacture of multicomponent fibers with advanced optical and electrical capabilities as well as scalable, well-defined complex morphologies. Applications span multi-scale, multi-component micro- and nanoparticle production; heterogeneous component integration in functional fibers and fabrics; and biocompatible platforms for regenerative nerve growth, recording, and stimulation, to aide in treatment of disorders such as Parkinson’s disease.

IRG-2 seeks fundamental insight into the molecular mechanisms that govern structure-property relationships of complex biological hydrogels, and to use this knowledge to create synthetic mimics with similar extraordinary properties. The fundamental knowledge and new materials developed within IRG-2 will lead to next generation materials with potentially wide-ranging engineering implications, such as the design of self-healing filtration systems for water and food purification, new means for enhanced and targeted drug delivery, and enablement of stimuli-responsive functional materials. New insights into the origin of the extraordinary properties of biological hydrogels are also emerging based on the fundamental understanding of the interplay between three common motifs found in biological hydrogels.

IRG-3 research seeks to discover the coupling mechanisms between oxygen defects and the transport of phonons, charge, and spin in oxides, and to control this coupling via electric field, strain, and electrochemical potential applied at interfaces. This fundamental knowledge is driving advances in functional materials applicable to memories and logic, energy storage and harvesting systems, electrochemical sensing, and nanoscale heat management. The research of IRG-3 has broad implications for energy and information technologies. By better understanding the central role that oxygen and other ionic defects play in the electrical, optical and magnetic properties of metal oxides at interfaces, this work will help enable the next generation of emerging ‘ionitronic” devices such as nanoionic and thermoelectric devices, fuel cells, and memristive and magnetoelectronic devices.

 Broader Impacts:

A broad educational outreach portfolio with a strong focus on diversity has led to substantial impact on K-12 students and teachers, undergraduate students, including from community colleges and from partner institutions in Puerto Rico, graduate students, postdocs, and the broader public. The MIT MRSEC has engaged >5000 participants in our portfolio of educational outreach activities, including ~425 core program participants (those spending a week or more at MIT) and ~4600 special program participants (MIT Museum Day, Cambridge Science Festival, etc.), spurring interest in STEM and impacting the diversity pipeline. Our diversity focused strategic efforts have resulted in a core participant (residential educational outreach, graduate students, post-docs, faculty, etc.) average of 49% women and 15% underrepresented minorities (URMs); specific targeted programs have participation levels with >60% URMs and 100% women. The MIT MRSEC operates state-of-the-art shared experimental facilities (SEFs) serving >1000 individual users per year from within MIT and at outside companies, universities and hospitals, and from institutions serving historically underrepresented groups through the Materials Research Facilities Network. Approximately 530 publications have been enabled through use of our SEFs. The research activities have led to technological and societal impacts in areas ranging from disease treatment, to advanced manufacturing, to emerging information and energy technologies.  Impacts include development of advanced functional fiber technologies for treating neural disorders such as Parkinson’s disease, development of scalable processing paradigms for multifunctional fiber-based fabrics, discovery of new drug delivery mechanisms for osteoarthritis treatment, and engineering of new functional materials for chemical sensing and nanoscale heat management. IRG and seed research has trained undergraduates, graduate students, visiting scientists, teachers, and postdoctoral associates in multi-disciplinary team environments with direct connection to real world problems through collaborations with industry. In addition, MRSEC researchers, including faculty, postdocs, and students, have made significant contributions to MRSEC supported educational outreach programs aimed at inspiring young people to consider a career in science and engineering and promoting public scientific literacy.

 


Last Modified: 02/28/2022
Modified by: Geoffrey S Beach
